description.narrative: The objectives of the Public Financial Management (PFM) Modernization Project Adaptable Program Loan for Tajikistan are to establish basic processes for efficient and transparent management of public expenditures and to develop adequate institutional capacity to support the implementation and sustained functioning of an automated financial management information system. The project includes the following components: (1) building capacity for PFM; the component will help build institutional capacity of the key Ministry of Finance’s (MoF) structures, develop management and technical capacity of core personnel in the MoF and budget organizations, as well as support management of the PFM project and more broadly the management of implementation of the PFM Strategy. (2) Streamlining core budget management procedures; this component will support: improvement of budget planning and budget preparation; implementation of the integrated chart of accounts and improved budget classification system aligned with international standards; improvement of procedures for budget execution through the treasury system; redesigning the existing information systems to align operations with changes to the budget classification system and chart of accounts; implementation of upgraded information system. (3) Preparation for automation of core PFM operations component; this component will be a support for establishment and capacity building of the MoF's IT Center; modernization of MoF Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) infrastructure, including an upgrade of the existing information systems, the ICT equipment for main system and backup centers and local treasury offices; support for change management (technical training, study visits for the MoF and IT Center staff and workshops); and preparation of the financial management information system technical requirements and procurement

condition.narrative: Finance Agreement :Sch. 2, p.3 | Description :The Recipient shall maintain the PGS with a composition, resources and TORsatisfactory to IDA | Frequency :Quarterly

Finance Agreement :Sch.2, p.7 | Description :The Recipient shall establish and make operational the IT Center and shall appoint adirector of the IT Center, on terms and conditions satisfactory to the Association | Frequency :Yearly

title.narrative: Budget preparation cycle is improved and integrates MTEF as a regular budget cycle phase

baseline.value: Budget cycle does not integrate annual and medium-term planning.

target.value: 2012 budget is implemented on the basis of improved budget circular incorporating MTEF. 2014 budget document consistent withstrategic planningand MTEF

actual.value: There is progress in applying an MTEF in the pilot ministries and local level. Medium-term expenditure frameworks were developedfor 6 pilot sectors and health and education sectors at local level. New budget preparation calendar and procedures wereimplemented. The work on improving coordination in the process of preparation of capital budget is underway. Performance indicators(PI) for objective-oriented allocation of expenditure were developed and implemented in order to measure and pursue sector- relatedobjectives.

title.narrative: Budget submission to Parliament, the Budget Law and amendments, and Quarterly and Annual budget execution reports are published on the MoF's web-page by YR4

baseline.value: Draft Budget Law or amendments are not published prior to approval. Budget execution reports are not regularly published. These arenot generated automatically, manual consolidation requires effort

target.value: Budget prepared and executed through an upgraded information system. Budget and Financial reports published on MoF's website

actual.value: Budget submission to Parliament, the Budget Law and amendments, and Annual Budget Execution reports are published regularly ate MoFwebsite.

title.narrative: Central and local ICT systems modernized in YR3

baseline.value: Existing Information Systems for budget preparation and execution have limited capabilities and do not support new BC and COA

target.value: Information systems for budget preparation and execution supproting newBC and COA are operational and used for 2013 budget execution

actual.value: The nation-wide MoF ICT network has been extended. MoF signed contracts for delivery and installation of data center and ITinfrastructure equipment. Currently MoF is installing equipment.

title.narrative: MoF's IT Center established, adequate number of specialists recruited and trained

baseline.value: No IT Center. Only 3 staff provide support to maintenance the existing information system. No capacity for upgrading the IT systemis in place

target.value: IT Center established and adequately staffed with trained specialists. IT Center capable to support implementation of FMIS

actual.value: MoF IT Center has been established and staffed. Staff has received adequate training.

title.narrative: The MoF has adequate technical capacity to implement redesigned procedures and manage existing applications, supprot users and sustain IT systems

baseline.value: Only 3 ICT specialists support central MoF IT systems. An IT Center is planned to be established by January 2011.

target.value: FMIS implementation starts with active participation of MoF IT center.

actual.value: MoF adopted a program providing for re-training of up to 10,000 employees of MoF on new budget procedures. The training of staffbegan in June 2013. Also 12 IT specialists have been hired who are helping MoF to maintain its ICT infrastructure. Also trainingwas provided for 17 IT specialists, which have been deployed on the field offices. It is expected that from January 1, 2015, ITCenter, which is currently financed by the Project, will be financed by MoF.

title.narrative: Budget classification (BC) and chart of accounts (COA) are integrated and brought in line with international standards

baseline.value: Only economic and functional classifications are used for budget management. Administrative classification developed for thecentral governmentbut not introduced . The COA is not aligned with BC

target.value: 2012 budget is executed on the basis of the new COA integrated with theBC

actual.value: UCOA based on GFS 2001 was implemented from January 1, 2014.

title.narrative: Improved capacity of the MoF to manage reforms

baseline.value: PFM Council established, however technical capacity to support implementation of the PFM Strategy is low. Structure and skills ofcore staffs poorly match organizational tasks.

target.value: MoF organizational structure streamlined, properly staffed and management and operational skills developed

actual.value: MoF has submitted its new Organizational Structure to the Government for Approval. The new structure is expected to enhanceeffectiveness of management at the Ministry. In addition to the Treausry, reorganization of HR Department and Training Center areexpected. PFM Secretariat is helping MoF with reform coordination and management.

title.narrative: The MoF and budget organizations practice streamlined business processes for budget preparation and execution

baseline.value: Preparation of annual budget is separated from medium-term planning, current expenditure is planned separately from capitalinvestments. Procedures for budget execution are underdeveloped

target.value: 2014 budget document is consistent with strategic planning and macro-fiscal forecasts, as reflected in MTEF for 2014-2016.

actual.value: In addition to 6 pilot ministries, MTEF has been extended to local budgets. Health and Education in the Khatlon Region and Dushanbeare implementing MTEF. The new budget preparation module and budget prepartion process were implemeted from January 1, 2014, whichstreamlined budget prepartion process. Streamlining budget execution processes is underway.

title.narrative: Sustainable training capacity is developed and core staff in financial departments are trained in PFM procedures

baseline.value: Staff has inadequate skills to implement PFM reforms, permanent training capacity is absent

target.value: MoF's Training Center delivers training program in PFM procuredures. Training courses developed and local trainers trained. 60% ofthe core PFMstaff trained

actual.value: MoF is implementing a Training Program providing for re-training of up to 10,000 employees of MoF (more than 60% of MoF staff) andbudget organizations on new budget procedures. The program implementation started in June 2013. Currently around 7,000 staff ofbudget organization has received training on budget preparation and execution, accounting, and a new information system. The newOrganizational Structure of the Training Center is expected to be implemented from March 1, 2015.

title.narrative: Procedures for budget execution through the treasury system are improved

baseline.value: Treasury procedures are underdeveloped and not fully documented. Internal controls are weak

target.value: Integrated TSA established covering country-wide operations. Budget is executed on the basis of the new manual for budget execution

actual.value: MoF is implementing a new organizational structure of the Treasury, which provides for establishing new budget execution functionssuch as cash management, commitment control and accounting. To support implementation of these new functions, the budget executionsoftware is being finalized, which includes commitment management and accounting modules. A new treasury legislation is beingdeveloped.

title.narrative: The budget is prepared and executed based on an upgraded budget classification which is integrated with the chart of accounts

baseline.value: Presently the MOF uses the old chart of accounts based on GFSM1986 and accounting standards adopted before 1991. Republican Budgetis prepared based on a new administrative classification since 2010. Economic classification is still GFS 1986 based.

target.value: Budget plan and execution reports are aligned with international financial statistics and international public sector accountingstandards

actual.value: New UCOA was implemented from Janury 1, 2014.
